feature.name: daily wage calculator
feature.description: The daily wage calculator is a payroll feature that automatically computes daily pay deductions for employees who take unpaid leave. It calculates daily pay by dividing an employee's total salary (basic salary plus allowances) by the number of actual working days in the month, accounting for the organization's leave policy (calendar days or working days). The feature automatically generates pay deductions that are reflected on the payroll table upon approval of unpaid leave requests. A critical aspect of the calculation is the deduction of public holidays from the working day count, ensuring that statutory holidays are not counted as billable working days. This feature integrates with the leave management system to process approved unpaid leave requests and automatically apply the corresponding salary reductions. The daily wage calculator ensures consistent, policy-compliant salary deductions across the organization and reduces manual payroll processing errors. It serves as a bridge between leave management and payroll systems, enabling HR and payroll administrators to efficiently manage employee compensation when unpaid leave is taken.

source_articles_index.title: How is daily pay calculated
source_articles_index.article_summary: Explains how daily pay is calculated for unpaid leave deductions. Documents the formula (Salary Amount / Actual Working Days), describes how actual working days are determined by subtracting public holidays from the baseline (calendar or working days), and explains how automatic pay deductions are created and reflected on the payroll table upon approval of unpaid leave requests.

source_articles_index.title: Salary Proration
source_articles_index.article_summary: This article explains how Super admins can update salary proration settings in the Daily Wage Calculator (DWC) by selecting calculation bases (custom days, calendar days, or working days). It documents the navigation path (Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation), the impact on active payroll transactions, and the special handling required when payroll months are open with existing prorated salary transactions. The feature affects employee first salary and end-of-service settlement calculations.
